    1 Regression

    1.1 Linear models

    1. linear model: coeffiecients Î²\betaÎ² are linear.

    1.1.2 Simple linear regression(SLR)

    y=Î²0+Î²1x+Ïµi y = \beta_0+\beta_1x+\epsilon_i y=Î²0â€‹+Î²1â€‹x+Ïµiâ€‹

    where

    • Î²0Â populationÂ interceptÂ ,Î²1Â populationÂ slopeÂ \beta_0\text{ population intercept },\beta_1 \text{ population slope }Î²0â€‹Â populationÂ interceptÂ ,Î²1â€‹Â populationÂ slopeÂ  are fixed but unknown. Estimated by b0Â andÂ b1b_0\text{ and } b_1b0â€‹Â andÂ b1â€‹ (whether using maximum likelihood or OLS, same result). Î²1\beta_1Î²1â€‹ means the amount of change in E(y)E(y)E(y) when one unit change in x.
    • (xi,yi)(x_i, y_i)(xiâ€‹,yiâ€‹) is a pair of data, plug in the formula: yi=Î²0+Î²1xi+Ïµiy_i = \beta_0+\beta_1x_i+\epsilon_iyiâ€‹=Î²0â€‹+Î²1â€‹xiâ€‹+Ïµiâ€‹ . The only variable in this formula is Ïµi\epsilon_iÏµiâ€‹.
    • Ïµ\epsilonÏµ is the model error, which follows the normal theory Ïµiâˆ¼N(0,Ïƒ2)\epsilon_i \sim N(0,\sigma^2)Ïµiâ€‹âˆ¼N(0,Ïƒ2).

      • It is iid(independent identically distributed). cov(Ïµi,Ïµj)=0,forÂ iâ‰ jcov(\epsilon_i,\epsilon_j)=0, \text{for i} \neq jcov(Ïµiâ€‹,Ïµjâ€‹)=0,forÂ iî€ =j.

      • Homogeneous variance assumption var(Ïµi)=Ïƒ2var(\epsilon_i)=\sigma^2var(Ïµiâ€‹)=Ïƒ2. (note: the unbiased estimator of Ïƒ\sigmaÏƒ is sss)

        s2=1nâˆ’2âˆ‘i=1n(yiâˆ’yi^)2 s^2=\dfrac{1}{n-2}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(y_i-\hat{y_i})^2 s2=nâˆ’21â€‹i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹(yiâ€‹âˆ’yiâ€‹^â€‹)2

        Some inferences:

    1. E(a)=aE(a)=aE(a)=a. E(Ïµi)=0E(\epsilon_i)=0E(Ïµiâ€‹)=0

      E(yi)=E(Î²0+Î²1+Ïµi)=E(Î²0+Î²1xi)+E(Ïµi)=Î²0+Î²1xi E(y_i)=E(\beta_0+\beta_1+\epsilon_i)=E(\beta_0+\beta_1x_i)+E(\epsilon_i)=\beta_0+\beta_1x_i E(yiâ€‹)=E(Î²0â€‹+Î²1â€‹+Ïµiâ€‹)=E(Î²0â€‹+Î²1â€‹xiâ€‹)+E(Ïµiâ€‹)=Î²0â€‹+Î²1â€‹xiâ€‹

    2. var(a)=0var(a)=0var(a)=0

      var(yi)=var(Î²0+Î²1+Ïµi)=var(Î²0+Î²1xi)+var(Ïµi)=Ïƒ2 var(y_i)=var(\beta_0+\beta_1+\epsilon_i)=var(\beta_0+\beta_1x_i)+var(\epsilon_i)=\sigma^2 var(yiâ€‹)=var(Î²0â€‹+Î²1â€‹+Ïµiâ€‹)=var(Î²0â€‹+Î²1â€‹xiâ€‹)+var(Ïµiâ€‹)=Ïƒ2

    1.1.3 Multiple linear regression (MLR)

    y^=XÎ²^+Ïµ^ \hat{y}=X\hat{\beta}+\hat{\epsilon} y^â€‹=XÎ²^â€‹+Ïµ^

    1.1.4 Ordinary least squares (OLS)

    1. A method to estimate unknown parasÎ²\betaÎ². in a linear regression model.
    2. It can be used in SLR & MLR (>1 regressor).
    In SLR, 2 paras Î²0,Î²1\beta_0, \beta_1Î²0â€‹,Î²1â€‹, and their estimators are b0,b1b_0, b_1b0â€‹,b1â€‹. Use OLS:

    minJ(b0,b1)=minSSE=minâˆ‘i=1n[yiâˆ’yi^]2=minâˆ‘i=1n[yiâˆ’b0âˆ’b1xi]2 min J(b_0, b_1) = min SSE=min\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}[y_i - \hat{y_i}]^2=min\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}[y_i - b_0 -b_1x_i]^2 minJ(b0â€‹,b1â€‹)=minSSE=mini=1âˆ‘nâ€‹[yiâ€‹âˆ’yiâ€‹^â€‹]2=mini=1âˆ‘nâ€‹[yiâ€‹âˆ’b0â€‹âˆ’b1â€‹xiâ€‹]2

    Use partial derivatives, tl.hen get 2 estimators:

    b0=yË‰âˆ’b1xË‰ b_0 = \bar{y} - b_1\bar{x} b0â€‹=yË‰â€‹âˆ’b1â€‹xË‰

    b1=nxË‰yË‰âˆ’âˆ‘i=1nxiyinxË‰2âˆ’âˆ‘i=1nxi2=âˆ‘i=1n(xiâˆ’xË‰)yiâˆ‘i=1n(xiâˆ’xË‰)2=âˆ‘i=1n(xiâˆ’xË‰)(yiâˆ’yË‰)âˆ‘i=1n(xiâˆ’xË‰)2=SxySxx b_1=\dfrac{n\bar{x}\bar{y}-\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}x_iy_i}{n\bar{x}^2-\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}x_i^2} =\dfrac{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x})y_i}{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x})^2} =\dfrac{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x})(y_i-\bar{y})}{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x})^2} =\dfrac{S_\text{xy}}{S_\text{xx}} b1â€‹=nxË‰2âˆ’i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹xi2â€‹nxË‰yË‰â€‹âˆ’i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹xiâ€‹yiâ€‹â€‹=i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹(xiâ€‹âˆ’xË‰)2i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹(xiâ€‹âˆ’xË‰)yiâ€‹â€‹=i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹(xiâ€‹âˆ’xË‰)2i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹(xiâ€‹âˆ’xË‰)(yiâ€‹âˆ’yË‰â€‹)â€‹=Sxxâ€‹Sxyâ€‹â€‹

    Because

    E(b0)=Î²0 E(b_0)=\beta_0 E(b0â€‹)=Î²0â€‹

    E(b1)=Î²1 E(b_1)=\beta_1 E(b1â€‹)=Î²1â€‹

    b0,b1b_0, b_1b0â€‹,b1â€‹ are unbiased estimators.

    var(b1)=Ïƒ2âˆ‘i=1n(xiâˆ’xË‰)2 var(b_1)= \dfrac{\sigma^2}{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x})^2} var(b1â€‹)=i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹(xiâ€‹âˆ’xË‰)2Ïƒ2â€‹

    var(b0)=Ïƒ2(1n+xË‰2âˆ‘i=1n(xiâˆ’xË‰)2) var(b_0)=\sigma^2(\dfrac{1}{n}+\dfrac{\bar{x}^2}{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x})^2}) var(b0â€‹)=Ïƒ2(n1â€‹+i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹(xiâ€‹âˆ’xË‰)2xË‰2â€‹)

    cov(b0,b1)=âˆ’xË‰Ïƒ2Sxx cov(b_0,b_1) = -\dfrac{\bar{x}\sigma^2}{S_\text{xx}} cov(b0â€‹,b1â€‹)=âˆ’Sxxâ€‹xË‰Ïƒ2â€‹

    1.1.5 Analysis of variance (ANOVA)

    1. partition of digree of freedom for SLR. equation: y=Î²0+Î²1xy = \beta_0 + \beta_1xy=Î²0â€‹+Î²1â€‹x
      • k = 2 for(Î²0,Î²1\beta_0,\beta_1Î²0â€‹,Î²1â€‹)
      • n sample size

    ![[df.png]]

    1. Regression hypothesis

      H0:Î²1=0 H_0: \beta_1=0 H0â€‹:Î²1â€‹=0

      H1:Î²1â‰ 0 H_1: \beta_1\neq0 H1â€‹:Î²1â€‹î€ =0

      • H0Â NoÂ regressionÂ relationshipÂ exists.H_0 \text{ No regression relationship exists.}H0â€‹Â NoÂ regressionÂ relationshipÂ exists.

      • H1Â RegressionÂ analyasisÂ exists.H_1 \text{ Regression analyasis exists.}H1â€‹Â RegressionÂ analyasisÂ exists. Then do F-test: test for the entire regression. Is the reg statistically significant?

        Fk-1,Â n-k=MSRMSE=SSRkâˆ’1SSEnâˆ’k F_\text{k-1, n-k}=\dfrac{MSR}{MSE}=\dfrac{\frac{SSR}{k-1}}{\frac{SSE}{n-k}} Fk-1,Â n-kâ€‹=MSEMSRâ€‹=nâˆ’kSSEâ€‹kâˆ’1SSRâ€‹â€‹

        where

      • k-1: df for reg

      • n-k: df for error Conclusion: Reject H0H_0H0â€‹ if FCALC>FCVF_\text{CALC}>F_\text{CV}FCALCâ€‹>FCVâ€‹ . Regression analysis exists. Note: F value can be used for ranking the importance of features. The bigger the F for a feature, the bigger the SSR, in favor of H1H_1H1â€‹.

    2. Hypothesis for Î²1\beta_1Î²1â€‹

      H0:Î²1=0 H_0: \beta_1=0 H0â€‹:Î²1â€‹=0

      H1:Î²1â‰ 0 H_1: \beta_1\neq0 H1â€‹:Î²1â€‹î€ =0

      • H0Â xÂ hasÂ noÂ impactÂ onÂ y.E(y)=Î²0H_0 \text{ x has no impact on y.} E(y)=\beta_0H0â€‹Â xÂ hasÂ noÂ impactÂ onÂ y.E(y)=Î²0â€‹t-test is a test for only Î²1\beta_1Î²1â€‹. Is there an evidence that x contributes information in the prediction of y?

        tn-k=b1MSEâˆ‘(xâˆ’xË‰)2 t_\text{n-k}=\dfrac{b_1}{\frac{\sqrt{MSE}}{\sqrt{\sum(x-\bar{x})^2}}} tn-kâ€‹=âˆ‘(xâˆ’xË‰)2â€‹MSEâ€‹â€‹b1â€‹â€‹

        Conclusion: Reject H0H_0H0â€‹ if tCALC>tCVt_\text{CALC}>t_\text{CV}tCALCâ€‹>tCVâ€‹. x has impact on y.

    3. R2R^2R2 coefficient of determinate

      R2=SSRSST=âˆ‘i=1n(yi^âˆ’yË‰)2âˆ‘i=1n(yiâˆ’yË‰)2=1âˆ’SSESST R^2=\dfrac{SSR}{SST}=\dfrac{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(\hat{y_i}-\bar{y})^2}{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(y_i-\bar{y}) ^2}=1-\dfrac{SSE}{SST} R2=SSTSSRâ€‹=i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹(yiâ€‹âˆ’yË‰â€‹)2i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹(yiâ€‹^â€‹âˆ’yË‰â€‹)2â€‹=1âˆ’SSTSSEâ€‹

      • 0<R2<10<R^2<10<R2<1
      • R2R^2R2 means the proportion of variation in the response data that is explained by the model.
      • R2R^2R2 on its own cannot tell you anything about causation. (causaion means that a change in one variable causes a change in another variable. correlation: there is a statistical association between variables)

    1.2 Generalized linear models (GLM)

    The differences between linear models and GLM. Standard linear model:

    • systematic component:

      y=Î²0+Î²1x+Ïµi y = \beta_0+\beta_1x+\epsilon_i y=Î²0â€‹+Î²1â€‹x+Ïµiâ€‹

    • Link function is one. Î¼i=xiTÎ²\mu_i=x_i^T\betaÎ¼iâ€‹=xiTâ€‹Î².
    • Random component: normal distribution yiâˆ¼N(Î¼i,Ïƒ2)y_i \sim N(\mu_i,\sigma^2)yiâ€‹âˆ¼N(Î¼iâ€‹,Ïƒ2) residuals are normally distributed.
    • Estimators: least squares or maximum likelihood will give the same result Not all situation can be considered as a normal distribution, large error.

    GLM:

    • systematic component:

      y=Î²0+Î²1x+Ïµi y = \beta_0+\beta_1x+\epsilon_i y=Î²0â€‹+Î²1â€‹x+Ïµiâ€‹

    • Link function is a function that delinearize the mathematical relationship between the predictors and the outcome. g(Î¼i)=xiTÎ²g(\mu_i)=x_i^T\betag(Î¼iâ€‹)=xiTâ€‹Î² . The link function transforms the prediction part, everything except for the Ïµ.\epsilon.Ïµ. You need to decide this when doing analysis.

    • Random component: Residuals ars not normal, it might be comes from a poisson, a binomial, a gamma.

    • have to use maximum likelihood

      ![[Pasted image 20240803223049.png]] [1] Types of GLM.

    two tpyes of varia: binomial. skewed, positive discrete distribution: poisson. # times you go to a doctor. skewed, positive continuous dist: gamma

    2 Time series

    2.1 Time series data

    1. assumption: observations at a certain point depend on previous observations in time. decomposition: Time series = signal(forecasts extraplolate signal portion of model; trend/cycle and seasonal) +noise (confidence intervals account for uncertainty; error/remainder/irregular)
      • trend: classical: MA, morden way:
      • LOESS locally estimated scatterplot smoothing:non-parametric regression method that combines multiple regression models in a k-nearest-neighbor-based meta-model. This technique is used to fit a smooth curve through points in a scatterplot, especially when dealing with noisy data. Steps:
        • Choose a point of interest.
        • Identify the neighborhood around this point (based on the span).
        • Fit a weighted least squares regression to the points in the neighborhood.
        • Predict the value at the point of interest using the local regression model.
        • Repeat the process for all points in the dataset.
    import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from statsmodels.nonparametric.smoothers_lowess import lowess

# Example data
np.random.seed(0)
x = np.linspace(0, 10, 100)
y = np.sin(x) + np.random.normal(0, 0.5, 100)

# Apply LOESS
smoothed = lowess(y, x, frac=0.2)  # frac is the span

# Plotting
plt.scatter(x, y, label='Data')
plt.plot(smoothed[:, 0], smoothed[:, 1], color='red', label='LOESS Smoothed')
plt.legend()
plt.show()

    2.2 Models for time series

    ![[Pasted image 20240805144951.png]] [4]

    1. Exponential smoothing models Apply a weighting scheme that decreases exponentially the further back in time we go. The larger the theta, the more recent observation is emphasized.

      Y^t+1=Î¸Yt+Î¸(1âˆ’Î¸)Yt-1+Î¸(1âˆ’Î¸)2Yt-2+Î¸(1âˆ’Î¸)3Yt-3+... \hat{Y}_\text{t+1}=\theta Y_t+\theta(1-\theta)Y_\text{t-1}+\theta(1-\theta)^2Y_\text{t-2}+\theta(1-\theta)^3Y_ \text{t-3}+... Y^t+1â€‹=Î¸Ytâ€‹+Î¸(1âˆ’Î¸)Yt-1â€‹+Î¸(1âˆ’Î¸)2Yt-2â€‹+Î¸(1âˆ’Î¸)3Yt-3â€‹+...

      0â‰¤Î¸â‰¤1 0\le\theta\le1 0â‰¤Î¸â‰¤1

      Simplify it, its prediction is like a horizontal line. So add trend and season terms in it. Holt winters exponential smoothing forecast:

      Y^t+k=Lt+kTt+St-p+k \hat{Y}_\text{t+k}=L_t+kT_t+S_\text{t-p+k} Y^t+kâ€‹=Ltâ€‹+kTtâ€‹+St-p+kâ€‹

      Lt=Î¸Yt+(1âˆ’Î¸)Lt-1 L_t=\theta Y_t + (1-\theta)L_\text{t-1} Ltâ€‹=Î¸Ytâ€‹+(1âˆ’Î¸)Lt-1â€‹

      Tt=Î³(Ltâˆ’Lt-1)+(1âˆ’Î³)Tt-1 T_t=\gamma(L_t-L_\text{t-1})+(1-\gamma)T_\text{t-1} Ttâ€‹=Î³(Ltâ€‹âˆ’Lt-1â€‹)+(1âˆ’Î³)Tt-1â€‹

      St=Î´(Ytâˆ’Lt)+(1âˆ’Î´)St-p S_t=\delta(Y_t-L_t)+(1-\delta)S_\text{t-p} Stâ€‹=Î´(Ytâ€‹âˆ’Ltâ€‹)+(1âˆ’Î´)St-pâ€‹

    2. consistency of distribution: can't have independece, but still want some consistency. Distribution depends only on difference in time, not location in time. same width(any size) of time, same distribution-strong stationarity. mean, var, autocorrelation depends only on difference in time-weak stationarity. Strong stationarity does not imply the weak one. Weak needs finite variance, strong does not.

    3. weak stationarity helps build stationary classes of models: MA...ARIMA not sationary: no consistent mean and var. 4.1 shifts in mean(not stationary): ![[Pasted image 20240804145903.png]] [4] common solution: differencing:

      • trend: look at the difference between the current point and previous one Ytâˆ’Yt-1Y_t-Y_\text{t-1}Ytâ€‹âˆ’Yt-1â€‹
      • season: look at the difference between the current point and the same point in the previous season Ytâˆ’Yt-SY_t-Y_\text{t-S}Ytâ€‹âˆ’Yt-Sâ€‹ 4.2 shifts in variance:
      • ignore when most models only model the mean
      • model the lack of consistency in var: ARCH/GARCH

    4. autoregressive models

      • forecast a series based on the past values in the series-lagsAR(1)

        Yt=Ï‰+Ï•Yt-1+et Y_t = \omega + \phi Y_\text{t-1}+e_t Ytâ€‹=Ï‰+Ï•Yt-1â€‹+etâ€‹

        target YtY_tYtâ€‹ , Lagged Target Yt-1Y_\text{t-1}Yt-1â€‹, ete_tetâ€‹ error.

      The recursion in time goes back until the beginngn of the series-long memory models. if âˆ£Ï•âˆ£<1|\phi|<1âˆ£Ï•âˆ£<1 shocks happens long ago has little effect at the present.

      You can also has n lags AR(n).

    5. Moving average model. Forecast a series based solely on the past errors-error lags. short memory models

      Yt=Ï‰+Î¸et-1+et Y_t = \omega + \theta e_\text{t-1} + e_t Ytâ€‹=Ï‰+Î¸et-1â€‹+etâ€‹

    ![[Pasted image 20240804224532.png]]

    MA(n)

    Yt-1=Ï‰+Î¸et-2+et-1 Y_\text{t-1} = \omega + \theta e_\text{t-2} + e_\text{t-1} Yt-1â€‹=Ï‰+Î¸et-2â€‹+et-1â€‹

    Yt=Ï‰+Î¸et-1+et Y_\text{t} = \omega + \theta e_\text{t-1} + e_\text{t} Ytâ€‹=Ï‰+Î¸et-1â€‹+etâ€‹

    Yt+1=Ï‰+Î¸et+et+1 Y_\text{t+1} = \omega + \theta e_\text{t} + e_\text{t+1} Yt+1â€‹=Ï‰+Î¸etâ€‹+et+1â€‹

    No more et-1e_\text{t-1}et-1â€‹

    1. ARIMA

      1. ARIMA first, make your data stationary (typically done throug differencing). Distribution depends only on difference in time. AR, integrated, MA.

        Yt=Ï‰+Ï•1Yt-1+...+Ï•pYt-p+Î¸1et-1+...+Î¸qet-q+et Y_t=\omega+\phi_1Y_\text{t-1}+...+\phi_pY_\text{t-p}+\theta_1e_\text{t-1}+...+\theta_qe_\text{t-q}+e_t Ytâ€‹=Ï‰+Ï•1â€‹Yt-1â€‹+...+Ï•pâ€‹Yt-pâ€‹+Î¸1â€‹et-1â€‹+...+Î¸qâ€‹et-qâ€‹+etâ€‹

        Deciding how many p's and q's. 2 techniques:

        • Plotting patterns in correlation
        • Automatic selection techniques: MINIC, SCAN, ESACF

        ARIMA(d,p,q)=ARIMA(#ARterms, # first differences, # Aterms)

        ARIMA(1,1,1) ARIMA(1,1,1) ARIMA(1,1,1)

        Ytâˆ’Yt-1=Wt Y_t-Y_\text{t-1}=W_t Ytâ€‹âˆ’Yt-1â€‹=Wtâ€‹

        Wt=Ï‰+Ï•1Wt-1+Î¸1et-1+et W_t=\omega+\phi_1W_\text{t-1}+\theta_1e_\text{t-1}+e_t Wtâ€‹=Ï‰+Ï•1â€‹Wt-1â€‹+Î¸1â€‹et-1â€‹+etâ€‹

      2. seasonal ARIMA: when data are not stationary. ARIMA(p,d,q)(P,D,Q)s

        • P: # seasonal AR terms
        • D: # seasonal differences
        • Q: # seasonal MA terms
        • s: length of season

        ARIMA(1,0,1)(2,1,0)12 ARIMA(1,0,1)(2,1,0)_\text{12} ARIMA(1,0,1)(2,1,0)12â€‹

        Ytâˆ’Yt-12=Wt Y_t-Y_\text{t-12}=W_t Ytâ€‹âˆ’Yt-12â€‹=Wtâ€‹

        Wt=Ï‰+Ï•1Wt-1+Ï•2Wt-12+Ï•3Wt-24+Î¸1et-1+et W_t=\omega+\phi_1W_\text{t-1}+\phi_2W_\text{t-12}+\phi_3W_\text{t-24}+\theta_1e_\text{t-1}+e_t Wtâ€‹=Ï‰+Ï•1â€‹Wt-1â€‹+Ï•2â€‹Wt-12â€‹+Ï•3â€‹Wt-24â€‹+Î¸1â€‹et-1â€‹+etâ€‹

    2. Neural network time series models input: # Number of autoregressive lags(AR lags): explore with correlation plots or aotomatic selection tecniques. seasonal data: typically include all lags up through one season unless correlation plots say you only need specific ones. STILL WANT TO MAKE DATA STATIONARY FIRST.

    3. Prophet model Time series = signal(forecasts extraplolate signal portion of model; trend/cycle, seasonal, holiday) +noise (confidence intervals account for uncertainty; error/remainder/irregular)

      1. trend lines with knots, logorithm trend...
      2. seasonal: fourier transformation
      3. holiday-point(pulse) intervention

    4. Vector autoregressive (VAR) model:

      1. model multiple time series at one time.
      2. multivariate regression is not multiple regression
      3. trying to predict multiple target variable at the same time
      4. when estimating 1 target variable, common: ARMA>AR
      5. when .... multiple ... , common: VAR > VARMA ![[Pasted image 20240805151510.png]] [5]

    5. Bayesian autoregressive models

      Yt=Î±0+Î±1Yt-1+...+Î±pYt-q+et Y_t=\alpha_0+\alpha_1Y_\text{t-1}+...+\alpha_pY_\text{t-q}+e_t Ytâ€‹=Î±0â€‹+Î±1â€‹Yt-1â€‹+...+Î±pâ€‹Yt-qâ€‹+etâ€‹

    6. ARCH, GARCH

      1. unconditional variance

        Var(x)=Ïƒ2=1nâˆ’1âˆ‘i=1n(xiâˆ’xË‰2)=E(xâˆ’E(x))2 Var(x)=\sigma^2=\dfrac{1}{n-1}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\bar{x}^2)=E(x-E(x))^2 Var(x)=Ïƒ2=nâˆ’11â€‹i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹(xiâ€‹âˆ’xË‰2)=E(xâˆ’E(x))2

      2. conditional variance: the measure of uncertainty about a variable given a set of information Heteroscedasticity-variance depends on external factors.(variance are changing)

        Var(xâˆ£I)=Ïƒcond2=E(xâˆ’E(xâˆ£I))2 Var(x|I)=\sigma_\text{cond}^2=E(x-E(x|I))^2 Var(xâˆ£I)=Ïƒcond2â€‹=E(xâˆ’E(xâˆ£I))2

        In cross-sectional data, heteroscedasticity: avoid In time series data especially in finance: we desire to model it. å»ºæ¨¡return æ›´æœ‰è§„å¾‹ã€‚

      3. Autoregressive conditional heteroscedasticity. Trying to account for time dependency and "clustering" of volatility. Volatility tommorow: Ïƒt+12\sigma_\text{t+1}^2Ïƒt+12â€‹ Actual today: rt2r_t^2rt2â€‹

        Ïƒt+12=Î±0+Î±1rt2 \sigma_\text{t+1}^2=\alpha_0+\alpha_1r_t^2 Ïƒt+12â€‹=Î±0â€‹+Î±1â€‹rt2â€‹

        why? Use squared returns to estimate a daily volatility:

        Ïƒt2=1tâˆ‘i=1t(rtâˆ’rË‰)2=1tâˆ‘i=1t(rtâˆ’0)2=11âˆ‘i=1t(rt)2=rt2 \sigma_\text{t}^2=\frac{1}{t}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{t}(r_t-\bar{r})^2 =\frac{1}{t}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{t}(r_t-0)^2 =\frac{1}{1}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{t}(r_t)^2 =r_t^2 Ïƒt2â€‹=t1â€‹i=1âˆ‘tâ€‹(rtâ€‹âˆ’rË‰)2=t1â€‹i=1âˆ‘tâ€‹(rtâ€‹âˆ’0)2=11â€‹i=1âˆ‘tâ€‹(rtâ€‹)2=rt2â€‹

        • volatility tomorrow: Ïƒt+12\sigma_\text{t+1}^2Ïƒt+12â€‹
        • actual today: Î±1rt2\alpha_1r_t^2Î±1â€‹rt2â€‹ ARCH(n) uses multiple lags in the past to model the volatility.

      4. generalized ARCH (GARCH).

        Ïƒt+12=Î±0+Î±1rt2+Î²1Ïƒt^2 \sigma_\text{t+1}^2=\alpha_0+\alpha_1r_t^2+\beta_1\hat{\sigma_t}^2 Ïƒt+12â€‹=Î±0â€‹+Î±1â€‹rt2â€‹+Î²1â€‹Ïƒtâ€‹^â€‹2

        • volatility tomorrow: Ïƒt+12\sigma_\text{t+1}^2Ïƒt+12â€‹ Real world data typically needs one of each:
        • actual today: Î±1rt2\alpha_1r_t^2Î±1â€‹rt2â€‹
        • forecasted today:Î²1Ïƒt^2\beta_1\hat{\sigma_t}^2Î²1â€‹Ïƒtâ€‹^â€‹2

    7. ECM Anerror correction model(ECM) belongs to a category of multiple time seriesmodels most commonly used for data where the underlying variables have a long-run common stochastic trend, also known as cointegration.[3]

    2.3 Model evaluation

    1. Prediction MAPE. mean absolute percentage error

      MAPE=1nâˆ‘t=1nâˆ£Ytâˆ’Yt^Ytâˆ£ MAPE=\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{t=1}^{n}|\dfrac{Y_t-\hat{Y_t}}{Y_t}| MAPE=n1â€‹t=1âˆ‘nâ€‹âˆ£Ytâ€‹Ytâ€‹âˆ’Ytâ€‹^â€‹â€‹âˆ£

      sMAPE. symmetric MAPE

      sMAPE=1nâˆ‘t=1nâˆ£Ytâˆ’Yt^âˆ£(âˆ£Ytâˆ£+âˆ£Yt^âˆ£) sMAPE=\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{t=1}^{n}\dfrac{|Y_t-\hat{Y_t}|}{(|Y_t|+|\hat{Y_t}|)} sMAPE=n1â€‹t=1âˆ‘nâ€‹(âˆ£Ytâ€‹âˆ£+âˆ£Ytâ€‹^â€‹âˆ£)âˆ£Ytâ€‹âˆ’Ytâ€‹^â€‹âˆ£â€‹

    2. validation: rolling hold-out samples: è¿ç»­çš„æŒ‰é¡ºåºé€æ­¥ä¸‹æ‰©å¼ è‡ªå·±çš„è®­ç»ƒé›†ï¼Œæµ‹è¯•é›†é•¿åº¦ä¸å˜ç´§è·Ÿè®­ç»ƒé›†ã€‚ä¸€æ¬¡å®Œæˆåï¼Œè®°å½•è¯¯å·®ï¼Œæ¨¡å‹åŸºäºæ­¤æ¬¡è®­ç»ƒé›†æ›´æ–°ã€‚ç„¶åç»§ç»­å‘ä¸‹æ‰©å¼ ç‰¹å®šæ•°é‡çš„è®­ç»ƒé›†ã€‚

    3 Nonparametric Regression

    Splines, Kernel, Locally Weighted Regression Most of tools in classical statistics are parametrics, they rely on assumptions about the underlying distribution of the data being studied.Techniques like least squares regression (which assumes normally distributed residuals) are parametric.Non-parametric machine learning algorithms do not rely on assumptions about the shape of the underlying data to work.
